div.p: When the Corps of Discovery made its way to the Pacific Ocean, the Arapahos lived between the Yellowstone and Platte rivers, moving across a large region of what is today northern Wyoming and southern Montana. Former planters of corn, the Arapahos by the nineteenth century led a more nomadic way of life, being accomplished horse riders, hunting buffalo, and living in portable tepees much like the later ones pictured here. They were allied with (and related in language and culture to) the Cheyennes, who are shown here living with Southern Arapahos on the Washita River in Oklahoma. External pressures from settlers, miners, and soldiers helped to divide the Arapahos in the years after the Corps of Discovery: the northern Arapahos were resettled to the Wind River Reservation in Wyoming while the Southern Arapahos, after fighting, were moved southward to the Cheyenne-Arapaho Reservation in western Oklahoma. Both communities survived decades of federal government neglect, poverty, sickness, and threats to their traditional way of life, and today are dedicated to preserving and revitalizing their language and culture.
